title: How to find the equation of line l that is tangent to the circle and (3,4) - Quora

response.answer_text: A2A by Adrianna Cauthen, I’m going to tackle this from an algebraic point of view, with just a little bit of calculus. The equation of the circle is [math]x^{2} + y^{2} = 25[/math]. So let’s find the equation of the tangent line at some (x, y). Take the derivative implicitly; [math]2x + 2y\frac{dy}{dx} = 0[/math] So, solving for [math]\frac{dy}{dx}[/math], [math]\frac{dy}{dx} = -\frac{x}{y}[/math]. Which gets us to the starting point of all the other answers, that the slope of the tangent line at (3,4) is [math]-\frac{3}{4}.[/math] Using point-slope form, [math]y - y_{0} = m(x - x_{0})[/math], [math]y - 4 = -\frac{3}{4}(x - 3)[/math] This simplifies to [math]y = -\frac{3}{4}x + \frac{25}{4}[/math]

Note that the slope of the line from the origin to (3, 4) is: [math]\frac{4}{3}[/math] Since this line is perpendicular to your line, its slope is the negative reciprocal of this. Therefore, it is: [math]\frac{-3}{4}[/math] So the equation for this line is of the form [math]y-y_1=\frac{-3}{4}(x-x_1)[/math]. Since your line passes through (3, 4), we can substitute these in to get: [math]y-4=\frac{-3}{4}(x-3)[/math]. This can also be written as: [math]y=\frac{-3}{4}x+\frac{25}{4}[/math].
